thread.title: WKU puts it away early, beats MTSU
thread.title_full: WKU puts it away early, beats MTSU

title: WKU puts it away early, beats MTSU
text:
WKU puts it away early, beats MTSU Aldo Giovanni Amato, agamato@dnj.com 6:40 p.m. CDT October 10, 2015 Blue Raider safety Kevin Byard (20) tackles Hilltopper wide receiver Antwane Grant (3). (Photo: Daily News) 10 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
BOWLING GREEN, Ky. – The game was over early, and it was over fast in MTSU’s annual meeting with rival Western Kentucky. 
The Hilltoppers crushed the Blue Raiders 58-28 in a game that was over in the first quarter when Western Kentucky seemed to be scoring at will. 
"(Western Kentucky) is probably the best and the most explosive offense we've faced this year," head coach Rick Stockstill said after the 30-point blowout loss. "When you get behind 21-0, it makes it tough to come back. We have to find a way to be more consistent than what we played today," 
As expected, quarterback Brandon Doughty had a huge day throwing for 359 yards and five touchdowns while surpassing 10,000 yards in his career. 
From the start, Doughty picked apart the Blue Raider secondary and put MTSU in a hole that the Blue Raiders could not dig themselves out of the rest of the game. 
Only one of the Hilltoppers scoring drives at the half lasted more than four minutes and to add insult to injury, Western Kentucky recovered an onside kick at the half to put them up by 38. 
By the end of the game, the Hilltoppers had put up 593 yards of total offense on MTSU. The last time a team put up 500 yards on the Blue Raider defense was Alabama on Sept. 12 this year. 
“We were sticking to the game plan, but we just tried to open up more and get our run-game going," MTSU receiver Richie James, who finished with 7 catches for 144 yards and two touchdowns, said. "Give credit to them; their offensive is explosive and they made plays. 
"It’s hard to catch up with an explosive offense." 
Despite knowing Doughty and the Hilltoppers would run trick plays, the MTSU secondary got burned one for a touchdown when wide receiver Nacarius Fant hit fellow receiver Taywan Taylor for a 69-yard touchdown. 
"We knew we had to keep the ball in front of us," Stockstill said about the Hilltoppers' use of trick plays. "They're an explosive team and have great dynamic, skill players." 
The Blue Raiders showed life out of the gate in the second half when quarterback Brent Stockstill started finding his receivers downfield. 
Stockstill’s most reliable receivers this season, Richie James and Ed Batties, finished the game with 183 yards combined and three touchdowns. 
“I told our team at halftime that I think we’re a good football team, and we proved that in the second half," Stockstill said. "Our guys are going to compete and pay hard and finish every play, so I was proud of how we came out in the second half and got another score on the board at the end of the third quarter." 
But Western Kentucky did too much damage early, and the Blue Raiders dropped their third game in a row and dropped to 1-1 in Conference USA. 
"We'll stay positive, and I have no doubts whatsoever about this team," Stockstill said. "We'll bounce back and get back to work tomorrow," 
MTSU will host Florida International at home next week and still has a chance to become bowl eligible on the year. 
But with Saturday’s loss, the wiggle room got a whole lot smaller. 
Reach Aldo Amato at 615-278-5109 and on Twitter @Aldo_ Amato
